title: Clarify Ethereum 1.0
body:
The Ethash section has two references to `"Ethereum 1.0"`:

> For Ethereum 1.0 we have chosen the first path.

and

> Ethash is the PoW algorithm for Ethereum 1.0.

It is quite ambiguous - there's no clarification of what Ethereum 1.0 refers to.
There's also one reference to PoC-4.

I think it's clearly a reference to `frontier`, but I agree that it might not be for somebody without any reference to previous versions. Perhaps it's better to clarify by referring to the rules at the genesis block? Do you have a better suggestion?

I think there is a good understanding what each of the "hard forks" or "milestones" had, such as frontier, but there is zero understanding among the masses about "ethereum 1.0". If anything, I'd just refer to the hard fork.

I'm not sure that saying 

> For `frontier` we have chosen the first path.

and

> Ethash is the PoW algorithm for `frontier`.

will make it any easier for those that don't know what Ethereum 1.0 means.
There is a way to find out what `frontier` means (though I would just include ```for the `frontier` release```).

To compound matters Ethereum researchers like Vitalik have referred to Ethereum 1.0 as Ethereum without sharding, while 2.0 is the first phase with sharding, followed by super quadratic sharding with 3.0. So I was very confused when I read how they used 1.0, 2.0 and 3.0, having first seen 1.0 here and also thinking it was Frontier.

I suggest to not use Ethereum 1.0 to mean Frontier, to avoid confusing the term with PoW, non-stateless, non-sharding Ethereum. However, I would say that in both instances when it refers to Ethereum 1.0, the actual meaning of Ethereum 1.0 being full PoW Ethereum without stateless sharding can apply. 

> Two directions exist for ASIC resistance; firstly make it sequential memory-hard, i.e. engineer the function such that the determination of the nonce requires a lot of memory and bandwidth such that the memory cannot be used in parallel to discover multiple nonces simultaneously. The second is to make the type of computation it would need to do general-purpose; the meaning of ``specialised hardware''  for a general-purpose task set is, naturally, general purpose hardware and as such commodity desktop computers are likely to be pretty close to ``specialised hardware'' for the task. For Ethereum 1.0 we have chosen the first path.

> Ethash is the PoW algorithm for Ethereum 1.0.

PoW and Ethash is used not just in Frontier, but every release so far as well as planned in Constantinople.

Therefore I suggest that we keep this as Ethereum 1.0, but explains what it means. You can do this without referring to future releases by simply saying that it is Ethereum with PoW. However, it would be helpful to give context and add what it doesn't include, such as no proof-of-stake and no stateless sharding.

Any comments on how to resolve this?

It seems like mentioning future protocol improvements in the specification is objectionable, so perhaps you can say: Ethereum 1.0 uses only PoW. However, to me, it just sounds vague to say this, without clarifying what the planned differences are in future versions, e.g. `Ethereum 1.0 uses only Proof of Work, whereas later versions will use \href{https://github.com/ethereum/research/tree/master/papers}{Casper} Proof of Stake, initially as a block verification/finality gadget with PoW as the block proposal mechanism, then later with full PoS; as well as other improvements such as for scalability.` While this is more verbose, it will provide an introduction to readers, most of whom I suspect will at least be curious to learn a little about what future improvements to Ethereum will be. Additionally, this can all be as a footnote.
"Ethereum 1.0" is a version talked about in the Yellow Paper.

As discussed in this issue, there are only two results for Ethereum 1.0 or just 1.0 in the Yellow Paper, and neither of those instances explain what Ethereum 1.0 is, nor what the planned differences will be in future versions. Without such an explanation the references are just vague.
Exactly.  A mystery for later historians to solve.
Oh dear, I wondered whether you were joking. How bizarre.
Well, it's like an old city hall.  It's partially a historical monument, though we also want to keep using it.

I kind of get your perspective but I still think it is odd. I think the main unstated reason you and Nick don't want to receive to make any reference to future versions is because they may change, and of they changed you would have to update the spec. However, I am fairly certain that future versions will have Casper PoS (there is already a test net for TFFG) and stateless sharding (implementations are being developed).
I'm not as sure as you are, and YP is not our place for speculation or prediction.

What is wrong with only using known (past) "hard fork" names as point of reference? Even if they are not explained in the YP they are many more resources about them online, then the ambiguous/mythical "Ethereum 1.0".
Was the name "Frontier" chosen before the hash algorithm?  If yes, the hash algorithm was chosen for Frontier.  If not, the hash algorithm was chosen for Ethereum 1.0 (later known as Frontier).

Alternatively: Since the YP tries to describe the current version of the protocol at any given point in time, it doesn't even provide a sufficient description for creating a client which can sync with the main net (e.g. lacking rule changes - hard fork point), one may just remove this versioning debate from it entirely.
YP currently talks about history.  What about "Ethereum 1.0 (also known as Frontier Release)"?

AIUI and as explained Ethereum 1.0 is not Frontier, it is all versions of the EVM specification so far (except for the Olympic pre releases) and also Metropolis. It is planned that Serenity will be the start of Ethereum 2.0.

What I suggest is that you define Ethereum 1.0 without referring to future versions as follows: `Ethereum 1.0 is all versions up until now of the Ethereum Virtual Machine specification as defined in this Yellow Paper, namely Frontier, Homestead, the DAO hard fork, Spurious Dragon, Tangerine Whistle and Byzantium, all of which are referred to \href{https://github.com/ethereum/yellowpaper/blob/master/BRANCHES.md}{here}, and excluding the pre-releases prior to Frontier, known as Olympic.` Then when Metropolis is released we'll have to change this and branches.md to include that, and when Serenity is released we'll need to add `and excluding all versions from Serenity onwards`.

Do you agree?
And we'll need to leave this issue open as a reminder to make those future changes and make pending PRs or merge PRs to the Metropolis and Serenity branches.
Or instead of saying `and excluding all versions from Serenity onwards`, you can say `up until Metropolis`.
I've created separate issues #653 and #654 (that should be beyond the scope of this issue), to address Alex's point.
@jamesray1 then I don't know what "Ethereum 1.0" is.
I give up, we are getting nowhere with this.
I don't think anyone knows what "Ethereum 1.0" is, hence this issue exists here

I talked to Vitalik at the sharding workshop, he said that Ethereum 1.0 is crappy, whereas Ethereum 2.0 is actually good, being scalable (processing a similar amount of transactions as Visa, or more), while being decentralized and secure. @vbuterin
Thanks for the insights. For now, I'd like to close this issue. Let's discuss that definition of Ethereum 2.0 in a new pull request once it's being proposed.

What was the resolution here? Change nothing and keep ambiguous  references to "Ethereum 1.0" and "PoC-4"? At the least it would be nice to have a footnote for those two explaining a tiny bit of context.

There was a comment in #595:

> Better to propose this in the correct branch which includes proof-of-stake and sharding.
